;中国科学界可能会告别向资助“打招呼”的做法

;

;中共中央纪律检查委员会和国家自然科学基金委员会今年已启动联合任务来解决这一问题。

;

; p>;

;“打招呼”涉及资助申请者试图通过个人关系接近和影响资助审核者。

;

;该基金会隶属于科技部，是国内主要的资助来源用于基础研究，并使用评审小组来决定支持哪些项目。

;

;评审基于申请人的过往记录，而不仅仅是项目的价值，一些申请人会寻找评审人试图影响他们的决定。

;

;根据该基金会去年 7 月的一份报告，在 2021 年接受调查的评审者中，超过 70% 的人表示在项目评审期间曾与他们接触过。

;<该基金会本月早些时候表示，自与中纪委成立联合工作组以来，已收到 58 起有关此类做法的投诉。这些案件已被调查，涉及不当行为的人被暂时停止资助程序。

;

;基金会还发布了一份目前被禁止的两打“募集”类型的清单，并做出了一些更改

;

;例如，在评审过程中，申请人不得与评审员入住同一家酒店，评审员在入住期间必须将手机等电子设备交给酒店工作人员。

;

;此外，评审人员在进入会议室之前不会知道申请人是谁。

;

;科学已成为全国关注的焦点，与西方的竞争助长了自我竞争的推动力。

;

;据国家统计局称，中国是世界第二大研发支出国，去年的研发支出超过 3 万亿元人民币（4,170 亿美元），占国内生产总值的 2.55%。统计局。

;

;尽管如此，对该基金会资金的竞争仍在加剧。从 2011 年到 2016 年，大约 24% 的申请者获得了支持，但到 2021 年，这一比例已降至 16.51%。

;

;一位研究科学社会学的教授表示，很少有研究人员从该系统中受益，因为其“赢家通吃”的结构。

;

;这位不愿透露姓名的学者表示，院士和知名首席研究员等高层人士通常会获得大部分资源。< /p>;

;能够加入这些团体的年轻科学家可以获得资金，而其他人则必须争夺资金。

;

;另一位研究科学资金分配和政策的研究人员表示，该基金会的规则在科学领域并不新鲜。 ”你好。

;

;“如果我们不能建立健全的审查机制，就会剥夺最优秀的研究人员的有效支持，这可能会对中国的基础研究产生深远的影响，”《中国新闻周刊》援引窦的话说.

;一名新加坡男子在尝试攀登坦桑尼亚的乞力马扎罗山时死亡。

;

;总部位于该城邦的旅行社Adventures Unlimited周六早些时候在Facebook上发帖称，它“收到了乞力马扎罗徒步旅行期间发生悲剧的悲伤消息”，预计该旅行将从8 月 3 日至星期五。

;

;“我们的一名团队成员 Darrel Phee 先生在探险期间丧生，”该公司表示。一位朋友告诉 8World News，他今年 28 岁。

;

;在 Facebook 帖子中，Adventures Unlimited 表示 Phee 的生命体征“在徒步旅行的几天里都正常”。

;

;“但是，在登顶的那天早上，他的氧气水平下降了，他的心率增加了，”它说——这是高原反应的结果。

;

;然后决定 Phee 不会爬山，然后他就回来了据 Adventures Unlimited 报道，根据安全协议，他在导游的带领下前往露营地，在那里他受到严密监视。

;

;“不幸的是，由于高原反应的发作及其严重的健康并发症，他的病情恶化了，他旅行社称，Phee 因窒息和高原肺水肿 (HAPE) 去世。

;

;马来西亚登山者因没有感谢从珠穆朗玛峰救下他的夏尔巴协作而受到猛烈抨击< /h3>;

;HAPE 是一种当液体进入肺部并抑制血液中氧气有效交换时发生的病症。美国国家医学图书馆 2012 年发表的一份期刊指出，HAPE 是“与高海拔相关的最常见死亡原因”。

;

;新加坡外交部在周日的一份声明中回应询问时表示声明称“一直在向死者家属提供领事协助和支持”，并补充说“向死者家属致以最深切的哀悼”。

;

;乞力马扎罗山海拔 5,895m（19,340 英尺），非洲最高峰。据攀登乞力马扎罗山网站称，虽然深受探险者的欢迎，但“超过 50% 的登山者患有高山病，这是一次极端海拔的山地徒步旅行”。

;

;乞力马扎罗山的致命事故非常严重Adventures Unlimited的Facebook帖子称，这种情况很少见，概率低于1%。

;

;但该旅行社补充说，高海拔、极端天气、登山者的身体状况以及所带来的身体挑战可能是导致死亡的原因。

;

;Adventures Unlimited 表示“仍然致力于对参与者的透明度和问责制”。

;

;“我们希望您能在这个困难时期支持我们，尽管存在固有的不确定性，但理解驱使我们作为徒步旅行者的冒险精神。”

;亿万富翁和社交媒体业务竞争对手马克·扎克伯格和埃隆·马斯克在网上发起了新的攻击周日，Meta 创始人宣称 X（以前称为 Twitter）的所有者没有认真对待拟议的慈善笼式比赛。

;

;“我想我们都同意埃隆并不认真，而且这是是时候继续前进了，”扎克伯格在他的 Threads 社交平台上写道。

;

;“我提出了一个真实的约会……埃隆不会确认约会，然后说他需要手术，现在要求进行一轮练习而是在我的后院。”

;

;马斯克很快在 X 上做出了回应，他去年购买了这个平台，以前称为 Twitter。 “扎克是一只胆小鬼，”马斯克发帖称。

;

;马斯克要求总理梅洛尼为扎克伯格之战寻找“史诗般的”意大利地点

;

;特斯拉老板表示，他将于周一前往硅谷：“等不及明天敲他的门了。”

;

;当一名 X 用户表示扎克伯格对这场比赛犹豫不决时，马斯克提到了一家以鸡肉产品闻名的美国快餐连锁店。

;

;“他不能在福来鸡吃东西，因为那会吃人，”马斯克发帖说。

;

;这两位科技巨头在社交媒体上就争吵问题争论不休。在一场大肆宣传的慈善比赛中彼此对战。

;

;马斯克周五表示，这场比赛将在意大利举行，意大利当局证实了有关举办“大型慈善活动”的谈判。

;

; “我与意大利总理和文化部长进行了交谈，”马斯克写道，他指的是意大利总理乔治亚·梅洛尼。 “他们已经就一个史诗般的地点达成了一致。”

;

;作为回应，扎克伯格发布了一张自己赤裸上身并在他的“后院八角形”中压制对手的照片。

;

;一位武术爱好者扎克伯格曾参加过柔术比赛，他说：“我喜欢这项运动，自从埃隆向我挑战的那一天起，我就已经做好了战斗的准备。”

;

;“如果他同意具体日期的话，你会从我这里听到的。在那之前，请假设他所说的任何事情都没有得到一致同意。”

;

;意大利文化部长根纳罗·桑朱利亚诺(Gennaro Sangiuliano)证实与马斯克谈论“如何组织一场唤起历史的伟大慈善活动”，但表示任何比赛“都不会”在罗马举行。”

;

;桑朱利亚诺表示，与马斯克合作的任何活动都将筹集“巨额资金，数百万欧元，这些资金将捐赠给意大利两家重要的儿科医院。”

;< p>;这两位偶尔远道而来的科技大亨，在扎克伯格的 Meta 于 7 月初推出了类似 Twitter 的 Threads 平台后，成为了直接竞争对手。

;

;埃隆·马斯克表示，他与马克·扎克伯格的笼斗将被直播周五

;

;马斯克周五指出，他可能需要接受“小手术”来解决“右肩胛骨摩擦肋骨的问题”。

;

;“康复只会需要几个月的时间，”他补充道。

;

;世界首富拥有一块将两块椎骨固定在一起的钛板，但他周五表示，目前“这不是问题”。

;中国以外全球最大的稀土生产商澳大利亚莱纳斯公司预计将出现大幅增长尽管前进的道路崎岖不平，但该公司仍利用西方国家的努力来结束对中国矿产的依赖。

;

;其首席执行官阿曼达·拉卡兹 (Amanda Lacaze) 还告诉《亚洲周刊》，她希望马来西亚能够实现这一目标，该公司已经在马来西亚实现了制造工厂十年，将准备抓住行业持续转变中出现的机遇（绿色转型的重要部门），并暗示吉隆坡可能会重新考虑其在生产放射性副产品的业务上的强硬立场。;

;稀土价格下跌导致莱纳斯的收入锐减至 1.575 亿澳元（1.0485 亿美元），大幅低于 2022 年同一季度报告的 2.945 亿澳元，但仍远高于 2021 年前的收入.

;

;总理安瓦尔·易卜拉欣 (Anwar Ibrahim) 政府已要求该公司（该公司在其网站上将自己描述为“对环境负责的稀土生产商”）在 1 月份之前实现工厂无辐射。此前 7 月的最后期限已于 5 月延长。

;

;稀土对于许多产品至关重要，有助于为电动汽车、风力涡轮机、智能手机、军用飞机和导弹提供动力。然而，精炼矿物通常意味着提取与它们一起混合的放射性元素。如果处理和处置不当，这些废物会对人类健康构成严重风险。

;

;莱纳斯四月份要求马来西亚最高法院审查其许可证，称目前的辐射要求与最初商定的不同。

;

;尽管有更新、更环保的方法从地下开采稀土，但提取和精炼通常依赖刺激性化学品，会产生大量废物，而且成本高昂且劳动密集型。

;< p>;“我认为，人们越来越认识到莱纳斯在马来西亚赋予了（政府）独特的地位，他们应该充分利用这一优势，”拉卡兹 8 月 2 日在亚洲《本周》节目中说道。

;

;这位高管对该行业持乐观态度之际，莱纳斯于 8 月 1 日宣布与美国达成协议，将在德克萨斯州建设一座新的炼油厂，以换取高达 2.58 亿美元的资金。

;

;“这不是一笔贷款。这是一笔赠款，这更好。”她说。

;

;鉴于稀土的广泛使用和相对丰富，稀土的名称有些误导性。它们的数量相当丰富，但通常只在特定地点发现少量。

;

;使用稀土制成的磁铁在高温下仍能有效工作，这使得它们可用于电动汽车和风力涡轮机。这些元素对于美国国防工业也至关重要。据美国国防部称，每架 F-35 隐形战斗机需要约 417 公斤（920 磅）稀土。

;

;早在 2010 年，美国就越来越担心中国在该行业的主导地位。那年日本和中国之间的争端促使北京实施了短暂的非正式禁运，因为世界各国政府逐渐意识到中国生产了 97% 的稀土氧化物。

;

;稀土元素的开采从此开始多元化，巴西、印度和俄罗斯等许多其他国家也参与其中。

;

;但根据国际能源署的数据，中国仍主导后期生产阶段，2019 年生产了全球精炼氧化物的 87%。那一年，莱纳斯在其马来西亚工厂生产了 12% 的产品，其中大部分出口到日本。

;

;据 Lacaze 称，美国、澳大利亚和欧洲国家缺乏支持该行业的政策

;

;“中国和日本的独特之处在于，政策是长期制定并持续得到支持的。不幸的是，在澳大利亚、美国和欧盟，他们往往在选举周期上做得更多。”她说。

;

;但现在，她认为情况已经开始发生变化，至少在美国，其《2022 年通货膨胀削减法案》（旨在通过投资绿色能源部分抑制通货膨胀）以及一项补贴磁铁生产的拟议法案。

;

;即使美国政府在明年总统选举后发生变化，拉卡兹预计坚持这些政策。

;

;“2018 年我在华盛顿时，特朗普唯一真正成功的事情就是在中国问题上让众议院两党结盟。因此，我认为，当政府更迭时，他们改变主意的可能性要小得多。”

;

;不过，许多行业分析师私下里对德克萨斯州项目的可行性持怀疑态度。

;

;拉卡兹承认，如果没有现金激励，美国就不会成为莱纳斯新炼油地点的首选。与马来西亚不同，美国不是一个“低成本司法管辖区”，尽管她强调这并不是因为吉隆坡的环境标准较宽松。

;

;简单的地理位置是另一个重要因素。美国距莱纳斯的澳大利亚矿场和东亚磁铁生产中心的距离比距马来西亚的距离还要远。另一方面，德克萨斯工厂面临着拉卡兹所说的“稀土旅游业”的风险。

;

;运往美国的矿石可以进行精炼，然后穿过太平洋运回日本或越南。

;

;莱纳斯面临的另一个问题是，进入一个新国家并从头开始建立复杂的行业总是充满挑战。该公司在 2010 年获得日本投资后，直到 2013 年才开设马来西亚工厂，并于 2016 年达到最大产能。

;

;莱纳斯在澳大利亚建设的新工厂也面临着延误，但 Lacaze 表示她“非常有信心”在马来西亚政府为莱纳斯设定的 1 月份截止日期之前启动并运行该项目，该截止日期将停止其位于彭亨州关丹工厂生产放射性废物的炼油业务。

;

;她说，目前的计划是澳大利亚工厂于 9 月份开始运营。

;

;最初计划提前开业，但 Lacaze 称该完工时间表是“任意的”，并且是基于设定的最后期限”我们的立场一直是，我们是在一定条件下被邀请进入马来西亚的。我们在马来西亚投入了十亿美元。随意改变这些条件是不行的，”拉卡兹说。

;

;莱纳斯工厂的放射性废物长期以来一直是人们特别关注的一个问题。尽管多次报告都没有发现污染证据，而且风险也很低，但过去的情况却很严重。一家曾经在马来西亚运营的三菱稀土工厂于 1994 年关闭，原因是被指控辐射当地社区。;

;政治风向可能正在向有利于其的方向转变，这对莱纳斯来说是有帮助的。

;

;曾经反对该工厂的政客们现在掌权后似乎正在改变态度。拉卡兹说：“马来西亚现在明白……这些[稀土]是新技术和新产业的关键驱动力”。

;

;马来西亚拥有自己的矿藏和产业——汽车、电子和石化——可以制造

;

;尽管如此，拉卡兹还是谨慎行事，表示在“整理”许可证之前，该公司不会在马来西亚“再投入一美元”。

;

;尤其是在美国铺开红地毯的时候。 “我忘记哪位总统说过这句话，但他说你可以依靠美国人做正确的事，但前提是他们用尽了所有其他选择。一旦他们决定这样做，他们就可以像其他人一样执行[行动]。”

;讲述一个好的香港故事，不能再依赖过去的剧本，因为环境

;

;香港从一个贸易前哨站崛起为全球金融中心是一个经济奇迹。在过去的美好时光，这座城市享有两全其美的好处：既是中国的一部分，又在“一个国家，两种制度”下截然不同。它因其在全球的影响力而受到北京的重视，并被世界视为通往中国大陆和亚洲其他地区的主要门户。

;

;如今，这座城市变得紧张起来，并面临失去魅力的风险。它迫切需要新的增长模式和扩大的经济基础。 2019 年的政治动荡（中国谴责其具有颠覆性和分裂主义）之后，实施了国家安全法并重写了选举规则。

;

;稳定似乎已经恢复，但不确定性仍然存在。许多人都说新加坡、上海和深圳超越香港。人才流失令人痛苦。一年前的智库调查发现，47%的年轻人对香港的未来感到悲观。

;

;更有害的是地缘政治恶化和中美冲突升级助长了“中国威胁”阴谋。皮尤研究中心去年的一项调查显示，尽管许多人认为中国的影响力正在上升，但 19 个国家中平均有 68% 的人对中国持负面看法。

;

;《经济学人》渲染了“中国巅峰”，反映了西方的怀疑态度。五月报告中的理论，得出香港输给新加坡的结论。香港面临以美国为首的西方阵营的疏远，西方阵营以“去风险”为名，寻求与中国脱钩。

;

;更深层次的复杂性在于，西方认为自己措手不及。关于中国的改革，假设它会走西方的道路。如果他们在中国看不到未来，他们就会抛弃香港，逻辑是这样的。末日论者预测这座城市的灭亡。

;

;但香港的基本面并不支持这种宿命论。除了住房负担能力之外，健康、教育、市政管理和公共交通方面的绩效指标也令人羡慕。大学和专业服务是世界一流的。文化演艺蓬勃发展。

;

;世界银行全球治理指标显示，城市竞争力跻身全球前十名，政府效能、监管质量、法治、反腐败等表现突出。不足之处在于“话语权和问责”和“政治稳定”。

;

;疫情后的香港已恢复正常运转。失业率已降至2.9%的低点。一系列刺激经济和吸引外部投资的政策已经出台。雄心勃勃的计划比比皆是，包括新基础设施、填海和新北方大都市，以及扩大 STEM（科学、技术、工程和数学）教育，以支持和培育创新和技术中心。

;

;政府官员和企业领导人谈到大湾区内的巨大机遇。迫在眉睫的挑战是专业人员和劳动力的短缺；因此，需要制定吸引人才和扩大劳动力输入的新计划。

;

;批评者认为，香港看似正常且充满活力，但却失去了先前由言论自由和政治多元化点燃的火花。

;

;确实是国家安全法与自由之间的紧张关系。但所有国家都有类似的法律。这取决于法律如何执行以及法院如何裁决和建立判例。

;

;这里存在一个悖论：悲观和不确定性与热情并存。这一切都与政治和观念有关，这将考验政府管理不确定性的艺术——在动荡的环境中提供确定性和希望。

;

;关键是中国的未来。三点很重要。首先，外部行动无法轻易阻止中国的崛起。尽管需求和投资受到干扰，其制造和创新技术能力仍然强劲。

;

;其次，无论你喜欢与否，其社会主义制度具有弹性。中国是一个大国，发展不平衡、地区差异和结构性矛盾突出。因此需要持续改革。党国有时会做出错误的政策选择，但有能力纠正它们。它违背了世界末日的预测。

;

;第三，中国不是在输出其系统，而只是作为一个正常大国寻求修改交战规则。当前的恐华症，就像恐伊斯兰症一样，源于邪恶的政治、误解和歇斯底里。

;

;现实世界是高度相互依存的。脱钩会伤害所有人，尤其是气候合作。正如国际货币基金组织指出的，中国经济增长缓慢拖累全球经济复苏。一个没有中国发挥其应有作用的世界是不可持续的。

;

;西方一些人押注印度取代中国成为增长新星，并选择淡化其结构性缺陷、政策内向性、宏观经济失衡和市场脆弱性。美国和中国都太大而不能倒。他们需要重新思考，以巩固某种形式的多极战略共存。

;

;香港无法控制全球政治逆风。但它必须充分发挥一个国家、两种制度的优势，坚持作为一个自由、多样性和包容性的开放城市。正如习近平主席去年 7 月 1 日的讲话所强调的那样，北京仍然希望香港在制度上具有独特性和包容性。

;

;香港成功的唯一秘诀是成为一个真正的国际城市

;

;如果缺乏制度活力和国际信心，这座城市对国家就没有什么附加值。如果它放弃活力和全球联系，它将失去其战略意义。因地缘政治而变得更加尖锐的国家安全担忧不应笼罩日常生活的方方面面，否则香港长期珍视的创造力和进取精神将会减弱。

;

;为了重新发现自己的利基，香港可能会我们通过“3S”测试来盘点一下——上海或深圳能做什么，上海或深圳不能做什么，以及与新加坡相比，它在哪些方面仍然较强。

;从促成竞争对手沙特阿拉伯和伊朗之间达成协议到提出干预以色列-Palestinian crisis, China's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East have raised Beijing's profile as a player in the region.

;

;These efforts have been at the state level and carried out through the Chinese foreign ministry and state leaders.< /p>;

;But China has also been engaging the region on another level, attempting to promote its own governance model as an alternative to the West by fostering engagement between the Communist Party and political organisations from across the Arab world.

;

;Observers said party-to-party diplomacy could help China achieve stable, long-term influence in Arab countries by engaging with ruling and opposition parties while expanding China's regional impact, exporting its governance system and building support on controversial matters such as the legitimacy of one-party rule and Beijing's policies in the Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region.

;

;Israel flirts with China to establish Saudi ties, but can Beijing broker deal?

;

;Jesse Marks, a former Fulbright fellow at the Jordan Centre for Strategic Studies, said the Communist Party's main pursuit in the Middle East was alignment.

;

;“Party-to-party diplomacy has several objectives, from normalising a one-party system among China's partners to cultivating and developing ideological political partners in countries of strategic interest,” he said.

;

;“In the case of the Middle East, party-to-party diplomacy has been employed to cultivate ideological partners or, at least, reinforce mutual respect for China's core principles, especially one-party rule.”

;

;The international department of the Central Committee, the Communist Party's top leadership body, oversees party diplomacy. Established in 1951, the department was largely tasked with handling ties with communist parties of other countries – especially the Soviet Union.

;

;Its mission gradually changed after Beijing and Moscow split over ideological differences in the 1960s, and it started to engage with more parties across the political spectrum as China transformed into an economic powerhouse.

;

;China shores up strategic ties with UAE as Beijing extends its Mideast reach

;

;One of the party's latest diplomatic efforts in the Arab world was in July, when the department held a party-to-party dialogue in Yinchuan, capital of the Ningxia Hui autonomous region – an area of northwestern China where Muslims account for about a third of the population.

;

;More than 60 party leaders and think tank representatives from 19 Arab countries were invited to the dialogue, which has been held every two years since 2016.

;

;Unlike the Gulf's monarchies, where party politics is largely prohibited, developing Arab countries – stretching from the eastern Mediterranean to North Africa – showed great interest in the Communist Party's invitation, with representatives from Syria, Egypt, Algeria, Morocco and Djibouti among those taking part.

;

;At the dialogue, one of the topics of discussion was Chinese President Xi Jinping's Global Civilisation Initiative, outlined by Xi in March, which aims to “replace conflict with conversation and exchange” and “oppose hegemony, power politics” – ideas that won praise from many attendees, according to the international department.

;

;The exchange of ideas is typical of the party's diplomatic engagement with the Arab world, according to Sun Degang, a researcher at Fudan University.

;

;“Unlike China's governmental diplomacy [to Arab countries], party-to-party diplomacy is not entirely constrained by diplomatic protocol. It places more emphasis on policy and idea exchanges,” he wrote in a paper published in the Chinese journal Arab World Studies.

;

;In 2019, Song Tao, then head of the international department, made clear in an article in party mouthpiece People's Daily that the party should “unite all the powers that can be united”.

;

;“The party's foreign work should … secure more comprehenders, supporters, and peers for the [Communist Party] and the socialist system with Chinese characteristics,” Song wrote in Qiushi, the party's authoritative theoretical journal, in 2021.

;

;Together with parties in Arab countries, the Communist Party has issued multiple joint statements touching on sensitive issues including Hong Kong, Xinjiang, Taiwan and the South China Sea.

;

;In August 2021, together with 28 political parties and social organisations in the Arab world, the department called for opposing the “politicisation of the traceability of the coronavirus” in the face of pressure from the West.

;

;Four months later, as the United States enacted the Uygur Forced Labour Prevention Act, the department again joined 33 political parties and social organisations from 15 Middle Eastern countries to oppose it.

;

;The Communist Party is also promoting its governance model to Arab countries as a path to development.

;

;According to Sun, most of the countries in the region with active party politics face economic and political development obstacles similar to those that once plagued China, making the Communist Party's governance model attractive.

;

;“China and the Arab countries are developing countries, and they all face the arduous tasks of reform, development and stabilisation. As the ruling party, the Communist Party has accumulated a wealth of experience in the management of the country, and this basic experience is of great relevance to Arab countries,” Sun's paper states.

;

;He added that some countries in the Arab world had yet to emerge from turmoil and conflict, such as Syria and Libya, while others were in a period of transition and faced currency devaluation, fiscal deficits and political instability, such as Iraq and Egypt.

;

;Parties from Arab states ranging from Mauritania and Tunisia to Lebanon and Syria have attended webinars hosted by the Communist Party to learn about its governance.

;

;Lina Benabdallah, an associate professor studying China's party diplomacy at Wake Forest University, said the developing world's new generation of political party leaders had looked to the Communist Party as a model.

;

;“Another generation of political party leaders is also inspired by the [Communist Party's] leadership, development efficiency and legitimacy. From China's side, there are real opportunities to forge very strong ties to these elites who are either now – or might later be – in power,” she said.

;

;But Marks added that Arab countries still had a long way to go to benefit from the party's governance model, which he described as being characterised by centralised control of the economy and strong social regulations.

;

;“The idea of a centrally led economy is desirable to many in the region, but the central challenge is that Arab governments – with the exception of a few – are not sufficiently equipped to manage such an economy. Social control is an expensive process, and governments lack money.”

;

;In 2017, Xi said the party wanted to engage other political parties to take a more active role in tackling world problems, and not to export the “China model”.

;

;“[China] will proactively push forward the construction of a global network of partners and will proactively push for political solutions for international hot issues and difficult problems,” Xi said. “We will not require other countries to copy what we do.”

;

;In his speech delivered in March at the Communist Party in Dialogue with World Political Parties High-level Meeting, a major forum for party-to-party diplomacy, Xi said developing countries had the right and ability to independently explore a modernisation path based on their national realities.

;

;Peng Peng, executive chair of the Chinese think tank Guangdong System Reform Research Society, said that by connecting with different parties, the Communist Party could constrain anti-China tendencies in Arab countries.

;

;“Some political parties have been anti-China or anti-communist, so exchanges with more than one political party [in a country] can be utilised to form a restraining force, and are also conducive to mutual understanding.”

;

;'Delicate timing': why Blinken's Saudi Arabia visit was a 'message for China'

;

;Since the national independence wave swept the Arab world during the last century, there has been considerable ideological turnover in the region as countries explore the best path to development.

;

;As a result, parties from across the political spectrum – from nationalism to communism to conservative Islamic politics – split power in these countries.

;

;A Chinese professor, who requested anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter, said China's party diplomacy aimed to prevent a power vacuum that could be exploited by the West.

;

;According to the scholar, while left-wing, pro-socialist parties are no longer the Communist Party's main focus for building party-party ties, they are still its closest diplomatic partners.

;

;“There are a lot of pro-socialism parties in the Arab region, but in the end, we find that it's the conservative and Islamic parties that have a real impact on the countries,” he said. “If you don't reach out to them, the West will.”

;

;Chinese leader 'personally intervened' to secure Saudi-Iran deal

;

;Wang Jin, an associate professor with the Institute of Middle East Studies at China's Northwest University, added that party-to-party diplomacy could also have cross-border influence in the Arab world.

;

;“There are political parties that have influence not only in one country [in the Arab world]. There may be several countries that have the same political party or a closely related party organisation,” Wang said.

;

;China has become more proactively involved in the Middle East, having brokered a deal for the normalisation of ties between Saudi Arabia and Iran, and it has offered to play a similar role in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.

;

;Wang added that by communicating with different parties in the region, China could find more possibilities for handling these conflicts.

;Hongkonger David Chiu Tat-cheong was in his early 30s when he decided to part ways with his father's business and strike out on his own somewhere else.

;

;“I wanted to go to a country that my father was not familiar with,” he recalled. “我还年轻，想创业。 That would be a bit more exciting.”

;

;That was the late 1980s. He set his sights on Malaysia, as his father, the late entertainment and property tycoon Deacon Chiu Te-ken had already left his mark in Singapore and Indonesia.

;

;After his first few small-scale property projects proved successful, Chiu moved to Malaysia with his wife in the mid-1990s to build a real estate development business from the ground up.

;

;“If you're going to embark on something big, you have to live in that country for two or three years because you aren't entitled to leave the place until you are familiar with it,” Chiu said.

;

;He brought with him ideas from Hong Kong such as show houses, common leisure facilities for condominium projects and smaller flats.

;

;“Things that felt ordinary in Hong Kong more than 20 years ago were very novel in Malaysia,” he said.

;

;His bet on the country paid off. Chiu's Mayland Group of Companies is now among its leading developers, with about 8,000 new homes due on the market this year alone, while his Dorsett hotel group operates about 4,000 rooms there.

;

;“Malaysia has afforded me a great opportunity,” said Chiu, who was honoured by being made a “Dato” in 1997 and given the title “Tan Sri” in 2005.

;

;The real estate tycoon, who is chairman of Hong Kong-based Far East Consortium, joined part of Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu's weeklong visit to Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia in July.

;

;Hong Kong leader seeks business deals on Asean trip, support for trade pact bid

;

;Impressed by the reception Lee received in all three countries, he noted that in Kuala Lumpur, the red carpet was rolled out at the airport terminal, something usually reserved for leaders of large countries.

;

;“That was quite an honour for Hong Kong and the chief executive. I was quite surprised,” he said.

;

;On the day Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim met Lee, Malaysia announced that it would extend visa-free stays for Hong Kong passport holders from 30 days to 90.

;

;That showed the importance the Malaysian government attached to the Hong Kong leader's visit, Chiu said.

;

;The chief executive also met Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Indonesian President Joko Widodo.

;

;Chief Executive Lee pointed out that the 33 arrangements agreed upon between Hong Kong and local entities in the three Asean countries would open more doors for further, deeper collaborations.

;

;Tycoons saw Southeast Asia's potential

;

;The Pearl River Delta has been China's gateway to Southeast Asia for centuries, and Hong Kong has been open to the region since its early colonial days as an entrepot.

;

;Savvy Hong Kong businessmen have long had a presence there.

;

;CK Hutchison, controlled by Hong Kong's richest man Li Ka-shing, operates Indonesia's largest container port at Jakarta through Hutchison Ports, which also runs ports in Malaysia, Vietnam, Thailand and Myanmar.

;

;Hong Kong, Malaysia sign 11 deals as John Lee wraps up week-long Asean trip

;

;Personal care retailer Watsons, part of CK Hutchison, is a major player in the region, and opened its 700th store in Malaysia in June.

;

;Li's son Richard Li Tzar-kai is making his mark there too. His streaming unit Viu has beaten Netflix in Southeast Asia in terms of monthly active users, while insurer FWD is seeking to list in Hong Kong after building a heavy presence in seven Asean countries through a decade of acquisitions.

;

;In 2022, the 10 Association of Southeast Asian Nations' economies combined were Hong Kong's second largest trading partner, with four Asean nations among the city's top 10 trading partners.

;

;“Southeast Asia nowadays is no longer the Southeast Asia we used to know,” said Jonathan Choi Koon-sum, chairman of Hong Kong's Chinese General Chamber of Commerce. “It offers diverse potential for bilateral and multilateral developments.”

;

;His Sunwah Group, founded in 1957 by his late father Choi Kai-yau, has witnessed a fair share of changes in the region.

;

;Known as the “Seafood King”, Choi senior made his early fortune by exporting processed seafood to Japan in the 1960s and went to Vietnam in 1970 to source prawns.

;

;His Vietnam seafood business not only survived through the end of the Vietnam war, but also thrived in the newly unified communist-run country, expanding to include coffee exports, real estate and finance.

;

;Sunwah's portfolio in Ho Chi Minh City now includes two luxury riverfront residential developments and a 23-storey office tower on the tree-lined thoroughfare leading to the iconic city hall. The group is also involved in a seaside resort development south of the ancient town of Hoi An.

;

;As a standing committee member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, the country's top political advisory body, Jonathan Choi has been facilitating exchanges between Asean and mainland Chinese officials and businesses.

;

;He said he believed Vietnam expected Hong Kong to be more than a mere broker or a “super connector” with the mainland.

;

;Using his own company as an example, he said: “They want the Sunwah Group from Hong Kong to invest more money, so we are a major investor. And after investment, we operate a lot of the projects too.”

;

;Hong Kong tech firms turn to Southeast Asia to recruit talent amid brain drain

;

;Mindful of the historically complex relationship between Vietnam and China, Choi said that in his business discussions in Vietnam and elsewhere, he always steered clear of either side's politics and focused on the mutual benefits of his investments.

;

;“People are wary.如果我谈论我与北京的联系，他们会认为我与北京有一些特别的事情要做，”他说。 “相反，我抛开了所有与北京的联系，只是一个来做生意的香港商人，没有别的。 They will feel more at ease.”

;

;Under Beijing's 14th five-year plan, Hong Kong has a mission to establish itself as an international and regional hub in eight aspects, including traditional strengths in finance and trade, and newer areas such as innovation and the arts.

;

;Brian Wong Yue-shun, an assistant professor in political philosophy at the University of Hong Kong, said businesses in the city hoping to tap into prospects in Southeast Asia should do more than be a gateway to the mainland.

;

;“Hong Kong needs to think more creatively about what it can do for Asean economies,” he said. “It's not just about Hong Kong serving its motherland, which is important, but it's also about how Hong Kong as a part of the Southeast Asian ecosystem can help professionalise and transform industries and sectors within the Southeast Asian economies.”

;

;'Pays to have good local partners'

;

;Hongkonger Hayden Lui Chi-chun has called Indonesia home for two decades after being deployed there by a logistics firm at the age of 23.

;

;Along the way he married the daughter of a Hong Kong businessman. Having lived in Indonesia for five decades and witnessed a string of political upheavals, his father-in-law always wanted to find a way to support less-privileged Indonesians.

;

;About 10 years ago – when e-commerce was in its infancy in Indonesia – his father-in-law asked him to start a new business that could make life easier for small firms in the country.

;

;Hong Kong and Indonesia sign 15 deals as John Lee touts Asean ties

;

;He quickly identified a gap that needed plugging – how to make paying for online purchases more convenient. It would also help small and medium-sized enterprises save costs in handling payments.

;

;Recalling what it was like at the time, he said: “Once I made my selection online, I'd have to make a transfer on an ATM machine, take a photo of the receipt and send it to the e-commerce platform as proof of payment. Only then would my purchase be dispatched.”

;

;With Hong Kong's Octopus stored value card in mind, he described the overseas experience of online payment to Indonesia's central bank, and in 2012, founded the online payment solution provider Ezeelink.

;

;Indonesia's e-commerce took off as he expected, but the real turning point for his business came in late 2019 when a new law was passed to require all online storefronts to seek a local permit.

;

;It sent overseas sellers scrambling for local partners and new arrangements to recoup revenues.

;

;By that time, many mainland vendors had begun targeting young Indonesian customers online, after being let down by the saturated markets in the West and stricter rules imposed by US-based e-commerce giants.

;

;Merely months after the new policy was in place, the Covid-19 pandemic hit, bringing a fresh wave of mainland sellers.

;

;“The Chinese domestic economy was not doing great and manufacturers had to make ends meet by opening up new markets to digest their stockpiles,” he said. “In response, we developed a new virtual account product to provide them a foreign exchange settlement service.”

;

;Lui's firm is now helping overseas vendors meet the local permit requirements and link their online storefronts to all common payment gateways of Indonesia.

;

;With more Chinese merchants making their way to Indonesia, he expected virtual account clients to make up about 30 per cent of his business by the end of 2023. He was also looking for a Hong Kong partner in the financial sector to provide financing solutions to online vendors.

;

;Hong Kong must 'facilitate' movement of more global firms to city: Paul Chan

;

;“As an Indonesian payment company, we have an edge in getting in touch with more cross-border e-commerce companies because of our Chinese background. With a common language and culture, we are better positioned to understand the needs of our cross-border merchants,” he said.

;

;The Asean–China Free Trade Area has been in place since 2010, while Hong Kong's free trade agreement with Asean came into effect in 2021.

;

;The city is now seeking to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, the world's largest trade bloc that includes China and all 10 Asean countries. City leader Lee said all three state leaders he met were in support of Hong Kong's bid.

;

;Lui, a deputy director of the Indonesia Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, said few Hongkongers were running companies in Indonesia and he hoped Lee's visit would draw their attention to opportunities in consumer products and infrastructure in the country.

;

;Hong Kong to enter world's largest free-trade pact in Asean partnership

;

;“We can gradually educate the local Indonesian team with the spirit and commitment we have in Hong Kong,” he said. “If you manage to build a more efficient team, you will definitely earn a competitive edge in this big market where competencies are uneven between rivals.”

;

;Having seen others burnt in the past, Lui and real estate tycoon Chiu advised Hong Kong entrepreneurs to secure trustworthy local partners to deal with bureaucracy and cultural complexities.

;

;Chiu said a proper understanding of local politics would also go a long way.

;

;“Hong Kong is such a society of freedoms that you can make a living even if you never talk about politics. But in Southeast Asian countries, you must have a clear understanding of the politics and directions,” he said.

;

;To that end, the Hong Kong-Asean Foundation has been running education programmes in universities to prepare students for capturing the emerging opportunities in Southeast Asia.

;

;The non-profit organisation was set up in 2022 by Sino Group's deputy chairman Daryl Ng Wing-kong to promote mutual understanding between Hong Kong and Asean.

;

;Foundation CEO Charles Chia said: “For any business opportunity to flourish, I think the first thing you have to know is your counterparty.”

;

;He observed a lack of understanding of market opportunities, including those arising from Indonesia's rich raw materials and the relocation of its capital to Kalimantan.

;

;While working to connect Hong Kong trade-related associations with their counterparts in Southeast Asia, Chia stressed it was also important to foster a better cultural understanding in the local business community.

;

;“Who are you doing business with?你信任这个人吗？这种信任必须建立在……理解习俗和信仰的平台上。 And that is obviously the bedrock of any sustainable, long-lasting business relationship,” he said.

;

;“Southeast Asia is diverse.因此，当香港人与东盟国家打交道时，与与泰国人和柬埔寨人等打交道时是不同的。 They are all different.”

;Around 3.9 million working days in Britain have been lost to industrial action in the past year, more than at any point since the 1980s, according to new research.

;

;Many of the strikes have been fuelled by real-terms falls in pay of more than 9 per cent in the highly unionised public sector, said the Resolution Foundation.

;

;Sectors including health, education, the postal services and railways have been responsible for 96 per cent of all days lost to strike action since 2021, said the think tank.

;

;Its report, released as junior doctors continue a four-day walkout, said high inflation meant average weekly pay for all workers was 4.1 per cent lower in real terms in the three months to May than it was in the same quarter in 2021.

;

;But real-terms pay for public sector workers fell by 9.2 per cent over the same period and for those in health and social care it fell by 9.8 per cent, the study indicated.

;

;The foundation said the strikes were not just about pay, warning that working conditions, exhaustion and stress also played an important part.

;

;UK government refuses to give way on pay as health worker strikes continue

;

;The public-sector pay squeeze also appears to have contributed to an increase in vacancies, with those in health, education and public administration 33 per cent higher in March than in December 2019, compared with 23 per cent higher across the rest of the economy, the report said.

;

;“The recent strikes from teachers and junior doctors reflect the fact that real-terms public sector pay has fallen severely in the past few years, as well as the stress and difficult workplace conditions frequently reported by workers in these sectors,” said Nye Cominetti, senior economist at the Resolution Foundation.

;

;“However, the inflation-driven pay squeeze should also be understood as part of a broader pattern of poor pay growth across both the public and private sectors, and falling pay satisfaction among public sector workers.”

;

;Thousands of hospital doctors walk out in latest UK strike

;

;“Going forwards, the government will need to balance fiscal caution with the need to provide a level of pay for public sector workers that reflects the very real difficulties faced by workers in these sectors, and ensures that vacancies in these sectors continue to be filled,” he said.

;

;“In addition, there should also be a renewed focus on improving pay and working conditions for workers in essential sectors like social care, that are largely not unionised, but which are still experiencing the effects of job stresses and pay squeezes.”
